clean_content:
Definition / general

* Infrequent, well differentiated, locally destructive variant of oral squamous cell carcinoma* Characterized by a burrowing invasive pattern, keratin containing crypts, minimal cytological atypia and low metastatic potential

Essential features

* Endophytic growth pattern with keratin filled cavities / invaginations* Minimal to no cytologic atypia* Intraepithelial and stromal neutrophils are abundant, often with keratin microabscesses* Microsequestra are frequently associated with bone invasion* Very low metastatic potential

Terminology

* Name is derived from the latin word cunniculus, which means rabbit burrow ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:652](29948589))

ICD coding

* ICD-10
  + [C06.9](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/C00-C14/C06-/C06.9) - malignant neoplasm of mouth, unspecified+ [C00 - C14](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/C00-C14) - malignant neoplasms of lip, oral cavity and pharynx* ICD-11: [2B6E.0](https://icd.who.int/browse/2025-01/mms/en#472349708) - squamous cell carcinoma of other or ill defined sites in the lip, oral cavity or pharynx

Epidemiology

* Mean age of presentation: sixth decade of life ([Imaging Sci Dent 2018;48:233](30607347), [Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2018;126:208](28479078))

Sites

* Rare orally; within oral cavity most commonly presents on the hard palate, alveolar ridge or gingiva ([J Cancer Res Ther 2022;18:266](35381797), [Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2018;126:208](28479078))* Most often presents on the plantar surface of the feet ([Ann Diagn Pathol 2005;9:134](15944954))* Genitals ([Br J Dermatol 2000;143:459](10951172))

Pathophysiology

* Unknown* No association with human papillomavirus (HPV)

Etiology

* Tobacco use and alcohol consumption are suspected risk factors ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol Endod 2002;94:601](12424455))* Chronic inflammation ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:652](29948589))

Clinical features

* Clinically, the growth pattern of carcinoma cuniculatum is indolent* Lesion often appears to be nodular and bluntly papillary (pebbly)* Surface of the lesions may have crypts / sinuses / invaginations that are filled with keratin ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2018;126:208](28479078))

Diagnosis

* Clinical examination of the oral cavity is the mode of initial identification of these lesions* Biopsy should be performed for histopathologic guidance in achieving a final diagnosis

Radiology description

* Bone resorption* Radiographic features may mimic an infectious process, such as osteomyelitis ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol Endod 2002;94:601](12424455))

Radiology images

Contributed by Zachary Raffensperger, D.M.D.  

[![Mandibular involvement by malignancy](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumRaffensperger01.jpeg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumRaffensperger01.jpeg)

Mandibular involvement by malignancy

Prognostic factors

* Locally aggressive with low metastatic potential* Has a favorable prognosis* Complete excision with negative margins is recommended management* Recurrence rate is low ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2018;126:208](28479078))

Case reports

* 56 year old man with a slow growing lesion on the anterior maxilla ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol Endod 2002;94:601](12424455))* 74 year old woman with carcinoma cuniculatum of the right maxilla ([J Craniofac Surg 2009;20:1270](19625845))* 82 year old African woman with a palatal mass ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2018;126:208](28479078))

Treatment

* Excision is general mode of treatment* Neck dissection is not always indicated due to low risk of metastatic spread ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol Endod 2002;94:601](12424455))

Clinical images

Contributed by Brendan Bell, D.D.S. and Gary Wilcox, D.M.D.  

[![Large maxillary mass](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumBell01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumBell01.jpg)

Large maxillary mass

[![Palatal mass](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumWilcox02.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumWilcox02.jpg)

Palatal mass

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Architecturally complex proliferation of well differentiated squamous epithelium that branches and forms keratin filled cysts or cavities* Cavities resemble a rabbit burrow* There is a predominantly endophytic growth pattern ([Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:213](34076846))* Minimal or no cytologic atypia is observed* Rete pegs are broad and bulbous ([Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:213](34076846))

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Molly Housley Smith, D.M.D. and Yareen J. Alawneh, B.D.S.  

[![Keratin filled sinuses](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumSmith03.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumSmith03.jpg)

Keratin filled sinuses

[![Endophytic growth](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumSmith04.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumSmith04.jpg)

Endophytic growth

[![Tumor arising from surface](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumSmith05.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumSmith05.jpg)

Tumor arising from surface

  

[![Minimal cytologic atypia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumAlawneh06.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumAlawneh06.jpg)

Minimal cytologic atypia

[![Tumor Architecture](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumAlawneh07.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumAlawneh07.jpg)

Tumor architecture

[![Carcinoma Cuniculatum with ulceration](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumAlawneh08.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitycarcinomacuniculatumAlawneh08.jpg)

Carcinoma cuniculatum with ulceration

Positive stains

* Elevated expression of [p53](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp53.html)* Positive and increased expression of [Ki67](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainski67.html)
    + Expression is weaker than in conventional oral squamous cell carcinoma or verrucous carcinoma ([Int J Oral Med Sci 2012;10:336](https://doi.org/10.5466/ijoms.10.336))

Negative stains

* Negative for [HPV](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainshpv.html) within oral cavity as confirmed through immunohistochemistry with an antibody targeting a wide spectrum of subtypes, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and in situ DNA hybridization for low and high risk subtypes ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol Endod 2002;94:601](12424455), [Head Neck Pathol 2012;6:130](21643820))

Sample pathology report

* Mandibular gingiva, left, incisional biopsy:
  + Oral squamous cell carcinoma, well differentiated cuniculatum type

Differential diagnosis

* [Verrucous carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityverrucous.html):
  + Has an exophytic and endophytic component+ Pushing, stromal invasion with bulbous rete processes+ Sharp stromal / epithelial interface with lymphoplasmacytic inflammatory response+ Keratinization is church spire-like ([J Craniofac Surg 2009;20:1270](19625845))+ Lack of substantial cytologic atypia* [Papillary squamous cell carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityscc.html):
    + Exophytic+ Thin, filiform, finger-like papillary projections+ Cytologic atypia should be present* [Squamous cell carcinoma, conventional type](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityscc.html):
      + Lacks deep keratin cyst formation with branching+ Cytologic atypia should be present
